description: A flowering plant whose rhizome, ginger root or ginger, is widely used as a spice and a folk medicine. It is a herbaceous perennial which grows annual pseudostems about a meter tall bearing narrow leaf blades.
healthBenefits: Contains gingerol, a substance with powerful anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects.
Widely used to treat nausea, including morning sickness and motion sickness.
May help reduce muscle pain and soreness.
Can aid digestion and help with indigestion.

potentialAllergies.name: Ginger Sensitivity
potentialAllergies.details: Can cause mild heartburn, diarrhea, or mouth irritation in some individuals, especially in large doses.

potentialAllergies.name: Interaction with Blood Thinners
potentialAllergies.details: Ginger may have mild blood-thinning effects; consult a doctor if taking anticoagulant medication.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Propagation: Grown from rhizome pieces (with 'eyes' or buds).
2. Soil: Well-drained, rich, loamy soil. Prefers partial shade in hot climates.
3. Planting: Plant rhizome pieces 2-4 inches deep in spring after the last frost.
4. Watering: Keep soil consistently moist, but not waterlogged.
5. Harvesting: Can be harvested about 8-10 months after planting, when leaves start to yellow and die back. Dig up rhizomes carefully.
sustainabilityTips: Store fresh ginger root unpeeled in the refrigerator crisper drawer for several weeks, or freeze for longer storage.
No need to peel young ginger; older ginger skin can be tough and should be peeled.
Use leftover ginger scraps to make ginger tea.
carbonFootprintInfo: Generally moderate, but can increase with long-distance transport (0.5-1.0 kg CO2e/kg).

staticRecipes.name: Fresh Ginger Tea
staticRecipes.description: A warming and soothing tea, great for digestion and colds.
ingredients: 1-2 inch piece of fresh ginger, thinly sliced or grated
steps: Combine sliced/grated ginger and water in a small saucepan.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 10-15 minutes (or longer for stronger flavor).
Strain the tea into a mug.
Add honey and/or lemon juice to taste if desired. Serve hot.

staticRecipes.name: Ginger Garlic Paste (Homemade)
staticRecipes.description: A staple ingredient in many Indian and Asian cuisines.
ingredients: 1 cup peeled fresh ginger, roughly chopped
steps: Combine chopped ginger and garlic cloves in a blender or food processor.
Blend to a smooth paste. You may need to add a tablespoon or two of water or oil to help it blend smoothly.
If using for longer storage, add a pinch of salt and a little oil to the paste.
Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 2-3 weeks, or freeze in ice cube trays for longer portions.

staticRecipes.name: Candied Ginger (Crystallized Ginger)
staticRecipes.description: Sweet and spicy ginger pieces, great for snacking or baking.
ingredients: 1 cup fresh ginger, peeled and thinly sliced (about 1/8 inch thick)
1 cup granulated sugar, plus extra for coating
steps: Place sliced ginger in a saucepan with enough water to cover. Bring to a boil and simmer for 30-40 minutes, or until ginger is tender. Drain.
In the same saucepan, combine 1 cup sugar, 1 cup water, and the drained ginger slices, and a pinch of salt. Bring to a simmer over medium heat, stirring until sugar dissolves.
Cook, stirring occasionally, for about 30-45 minutes, or until ginger becomes translucent and the syrup thickens (reaches about 225°F/107°C on a candy thermometer).
Remove ginger slices with a slotted spoon and place them on a wire rack set over a baking sheet to dry for several hours or overnight.
Once slightly tacky but not wet, toss the ginger slices in extra granulated sugar to coat.
Store candied ginger in an airtight container at room temperature.
